newsitem.title: SPAIN: NATO opens historic enlargement summit.
newsitem.headline: NATO opens historic enlargement summit.

text.p: NATO leaders opened an historic summit on Tuesday, reported by officials to be close to an agreement on inviting three former communist states -- Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary -- to join the Western alliance.

U.S. President Bill Clinton was the last of the 16 leaders to arrive at the Municipal Congress Centre near Madrid airport and was accompanied to the meeting by Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar and NATO Secretary-General Javier Solana.
NATO officials said senior alliance diplomats had made "considerable progress" in overcoming differences on enlargement in negotiations that ran into the early hours of Tuesday.

A majority of nations, led by France and Italy, which wanted Romania and Slovenia in the first wave of east European states to join, seemed willing to accept just three in exchange for a strong commitment to an "open door" for later entrants.
However there was no agreement on whether to identify by name the countries which might qualify next, the officials said.
Solana said in his opening address that the summit was "a defining moment for NATO. We will open the doors of this Alliance to the first new members from Central and Eastern Europe."
